definition:
Folate, also known as
vitamin B9 and folacin, is one of the B vitamins. Manufactured
folic acid, which is converted into folate by the body, is used as a
dietary supplement and in food fortification as it is more stable
during processing and storage. Folate is required for the body to
make DNA and RNA and metabolise amino acids necessary for cell
division. As humans cannot make folate, it is required in the
diet, making it an essential nutrient. It occurs naturally in many
foods. The recommended adult daily intake of folate in the U.S.
is 400 micrograms from foods or dietary supplements. Folate in the
form of folic acid is used to treat anemia caused by folate
deficiency. Folic acid is also used as a supplement by women during
pregnancy to reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the
baby. Low levels in early pregnancy are believed to be the
cause of more than half of babies born with NTDs. More than 80
countries use either mandatory or voluntary fortification of certain
foods with folic acid as a measure to decrease the rate of NTDs.
Long-term supplementation with relatively large amounts of folic acid
is associated with small reduction in the risk of stroke and an
increased risk of prostate cancer. There are concerns that large
amounts of supplemental folic acid can hide &%VitaminB12
deficiency.[from Wikipedia]
